user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseDelete:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseDelete(osal_id_t timer_id)
{
    int32             return_code;
    osal_objtype_t    objtype;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /*
     * Check our context.  Not allowed to use the timer API from a timer callback.
     * Just interested in the object type returned.
     */
    objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(OS_TaskGetId_Impl());
    if (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, timer_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_TimeBaseDelete_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimeBaseDelete:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_objtype_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE 0x08
...
#define OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE (-35)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the function and related symbol definitions for use of compiler-specific language extensions. The code contains only standard C constructs: typedefs, integer macros and literals, variable declarations, function calls, comparisons, and return statements. There are no uses of known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm / inline assembly, __builtin_*, __typeof__, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, labels-as-values, __extension__, __declspec, pragma GCC/clang/msvc extensions, or other vendor-specific keywords. Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions).
